description: From Middle English cariage, from Old Northern French cariage, from carier (“to carry”).

examples: The remainder of the men were employed in unbarreling our Pork and stringing it on poles for convenience of carriage, and carrying our Batteaux from the river to the pond.

entries.meaning: A (mostly four-wheeled) lighter vehicle chiefly designed to transport people, generally drawn by horse power.
examples: Antonym: (heavier vehicle designed to transport people or goods) wagon
The carriage ride was very romantic.

entries.meaning: (rail transport, Britain, Abbreviation of railway carriage) A railroad car
The manner or posture in which one holds or positions a body part, such as one's arm or head.
examples: The runner has a very low arm carriage.

entries.meaning: (now rare) A manner of walking and moving in general; how one carries oneself, bearing, gait.
examples: Cavett: What would it take – seriously – for a musician to be good enough to play in the Miles Davis bands? Suppose you're looking for a new guy.
Davis: Well, the first thing he needs do – whoever he is – has to have good carriage, you know.
Davis: Meaning that they have to look like what they're going to play – the instrument.

entries.meaning: (archaic) One's behaviour, or way of conducting oneself towards others.
examples: He now assumed a carriage to me so very different from what he had lately worn, and so nearly resembling his behaviour the first week of our marriage, that  […]  he might, possibly, have rekindled my fondness for him.

entries.meaning: The part of a typewriter supporting the paper.
The charge made for conveying (especially in the phrases carriage forward, when the charge is to be paid by the receiver, and carriage paid).
examples: Synonyms: freight, freightage, cartage, charge, rate
